_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Agropur is a dairy product manufacturer located in the City of Weyauwega, Waupaca

County, Wisconsin. The facility produces cheese from milk purchased from area farmers.

The processing of these dairy products requires the use of anhydrous ammonia. Milk that arrives at the

facility, as well as the products produced at the facility must be kept refrigerated to maintain quality and

shelf-life. As a result of this need for refrigeration, Agropur utilizes an anhydrous ammonia system. The

system contains approximately 13,343 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.



Ammonia, although a necessary component of Agropur's processing, can be dangerous to employees and

contractors, as well as the general public in the vicinity of the plant if released in an uncontrolled manner in

sufficient quantities. Agropur has recognized the inherent risks with the use of anhydrous ammonia and has

developed and implemented a Risk Management Program (RMP) to: prevent accidental releases of ammonia;

and, respond appropriately to accidental releases of ammonia.



Agropur's prevention program for ammonia consists of the following elements.



1) Safety information for ammonia has been gathered and evaluated to assist Agropur employees in

understanding the hazards associated with the process. This information formed a basis for other prevention

program elements to minimize the potential for accidental releases.

2) A process hazard assessment (PHA) was completed. The purpose of the evaluation was to identify, evaluate and control

the hazards of the process.



3) Written standard operating procedures (SOPs) were developed so employees and contractors have access to written instructions for the safe operation and maintenance of the ammonia process.



4) Employees at Agropur have been trained, and will continue to be trained, on the job and in the classroom,

on aspects of the prevention program and the emergency action plan (EAP).



5) A preventive maintenance system has been developed to ass

ure components of the ammonia system are

in good working order.



6) Any modifications to the ammonia system will be carefully evaluated and engineered to confirm the

changes made will maintain a safe working system. Prior to startup of any new or modified system, Agropur

will conduct a comprehensive evaluation of the changes and modify the RMP to incorporate the new or

modified system.



7) Employees at Agropur have been part of the development of the RMP and will have a role in the continuous

improvement of the program.



8) Any incident, accident or near miss associated with the ammonia system will be investigated thoroughly

and promptly with a committment to make improvements to the RMP.



9) As part of the continuous improvement process, Agropur will conduct audits at least once every three (3)

years to identify and correct any parts of the RMP that are not functioning up to their standards. These

audits are in addition to the continuous improvement process.



10) Agropur will make sure its contractors onsite are aware of the hazards associated with the ammonia

system to protect all parties (contractors, employees, neighbors). For specific tasks that require an even

higher degree of oversight (such as welding, cutting or grinding around the ammonia system components),

Agropur will require its employees and contractors to obtain internal permits for hot work that mandate

special prevention measures.



Agropur has developed and implemented an EAP to protect public health, the

environment and onsite employees and contractors. Employees have been trained on the aspects of the

facility's Emergency Action Plan. Systems are in place to inform the public and the Waupaca County Emergency Government

in the event of a release.



Although the main purpose of the Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions (40 CFR 68) is to develop and

implement programs to prevent releases of toxic substances and accidents with flammable substances, the

federal rule als

o required that Agropur complete an analysis of theoretical impacts of catastrophic accidents

on the site. These scenarios were determined using the EPA's RMPComp online tool.



Agropur has not had an accident with ammonia in the last five (5) years that would require reporting under this rule.

Agropur has demonstrated their committment to minimize the potential for accidental releases and thus protect their employees, neighbors and the surrounding environment in the following manner:



  - committing significant resources to the training of operation and maintenance personnel;

  - hiring external consultants and contractors to provide a high level of program competance; and,

  - dedicating themselves to the continuous improvement of the prevention program at Agropur to further minimize the potential for accidental exposures.
